text: 4-7-8 Breathing Exercise: Inhale through your nose for 4 counts, hold your breath for 7 counts, then exhale through your mouth for 8 counts. This technique activates the parasympathetic nervous system and helps reduce anxiety by slowing your heart rate and promoting relaxation.

Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Excessive anxiety and worry occurring more days than not for at least 6 months. Symptoms include restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, and sleep disturbances. The anxiety is difficult to control and causes significant distress or impairment.

Major Depressive Disorder (MDD): Presence of at least 5 symptoms for 2+ weeks, including depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure. Additional symptoms may include significant weight changes, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, concentration difficulties, and recurrent thoughts of death.

5-4-3-2-1 Grounding Technique: Identify 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste. This mindfulness exercise helps redirect attention away from anxious thoughts and grounds you in the present moment.
Crisis Text Line: Text HOME to 741741 for free, 24/7 crisis support via text message

Thought Challenging: When experiencing negative thoughts, ask yourself: Is this thought realistic? What evidence supports or contradicts it? What would I tell a friend in this situation? This technique helps identify and modify cognitive distortions that contribute to emotional distress.

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): Develops after exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence. Symptoms include intrusive memories, avoidance of trauma-related stimuli, negative alterations in mood/cognition, and alterations in arousal/reactivity lasting more than one month.
SAMHSA National Helpline: 1-800-662-4357 - Free, confidential, 24/7 treatment referral service for mental health and substance use disorders

Progressive Muscle Relaxation: Starting with your toes, tense each muscle group for 5 seconds, then release and notice the contrast. Work your way up through your body. This technique helps reduce physical tension and promotes awareness of the difference between tension and relaxation.

Sleep Hygiene: Maintain a consistent sleep schedule, create a relaxing bedtime routine, avoid screens 1 hour before bed, keep your bedroom cool and dark, and limit caffeine after 2 PM. Quality sleep is fundamental to mental health and emotional regulation.

Suicide Warning Signs: Talking about wanting to die, feeling hopeless or trapped, extreme mood swings, withdrawing from activities, giving away possessions, increased substance use, and expressing feelings of being a burden. Take all warning signs seriously and seek immediate help.
